metadata.title: Bell OH-58 Kiowa
aws::graph::propositions: # Bell OH-58 Kiowa in the Gulf War
Bell OH-58D Kiowa is a helicopter.
During Operation Desert Shield, U.S. Army OH-58Ds would exercise alongside United States Marine Corps (USMC) AH-1Ws.
During Operation Desert Shield, OH-58Ds would assist with targeting.
During Operation Desert Shield, OH-58Ds would assist with laser spotting.
The tactic of OH-58Ds working with AH-1Ws was effective.
There is little evidence that the tactic of OH-58Ds working with AH-1Ws was used during actual operations.
The limited use of the tactic was likely due to a lack of OH-58D helicopters.
Operation Desert Shield was the build-up to Operation Desert Storm.
During Operation Desert Storm, 130 OH-58D helicopters were deployed.
OH-58D helicopters worked alongside other Army attack helicopters during Operation Desert Storm.
The Army deployed 145 AH-1 Cobras during Operation Desert Storm.
The Army deployed 277 AH-64 Apaches during Operation Desert Storm.
OH-58D helicopters participated in a wide variety of critical combat ground forces missions during Operation Desert Storm.
During Operation Desert Shield and Operation Desert Storm, Kiowa helicopters collectively flew nearly 9,000 hours.
Kiowa helicopters maintained a 92 percent fully mission capable rate during Operations Desert Shield and Desert Storm.
The Kiowa Warrior had the lowest ratio of maintenance hours to flight hours of any combat helicopter in the Gulf War.

complement.value: lowest ratio of maintenance hours to flight hours

text:
### Gulf War
During Operation Desert Shield (the build-up to Operation Desert Storm) U.S. Army OH-58Ds would exercise alongside USMC AH-1Ws and assist with targeting and laser spotting. However while this tactic worked and was effective, there is little evidence that this tactic was used, likely to a lack of OD-58Ds.

During Operation Desert Storm, 130 deployed OH-58D helicopters worked alongside the other Army attack helicopters, 145 AH-1 Cobras and 277 AH-64 Apaches, and participated in a wide variety of critical combat ground forces mission. During Operation Desert Shield and Operation Desert Storm, the Kiowas collectively flew nearly 9,000 hours with a 92 percent fully mission capable rate. The Kiowa Warrior had the lowest ratio of maintenance hours to flight hours of any combat helicopter in the war.
